answers.explanation:
On fundus examination, there are RPE changes near the fovea. On OCT, these pigmentary changes correlate with a hyper-reflective lesion under the fovea that presents as a raised separation between the RPE and Bruch’s Membrane. These findings are consistent with a pigment epithelial detachment. There are also several foci of hyper-reflective spots anterior to the PED. Subretinal fluid would appear hypo-reflective rather than hyper-reflective and often accumulates between the outer retina and RPE. There is no geographic atrophy seen on OCT. 

![](/content/media/r59_5.webp)

![](/content/media/r59_6.webp)

In this separate OCT image, several hyper-reflective foci can also be seen here overlying drusenoid deposits in a patient with dry AMD. 

![](/content/media/r59_7.webp)

answers.explanation: Histological studies have shown that in AMD presenting with drusenoid deposits, intraretinal hyper-reflective foci above the drusen are fully pigmented and nucleated RPE cells migrating anteriorly and likely represent progression of the disease.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What does the presence of hyper-reflective foci mean for the prognosis in this patient?

answers.answerText: A. Greater risk of retinal detachments
B. Greater risk of developing a macular hole
C. Greater risk of developing geographic atrophy
answers.explanation: Drusens are a common finding in advanced AMD subtypes. With drusenoid PEDs, some studies have found a 50% chance of progression to geographic atrophy within 7 years, and this becomes reduced to 2 years if the drusen is larger than 2 disc-diameters or metamorphopsia is present in the initial visit. As RPE cells migrate anteriorly (presenting as hyper-reflective foci), the pigment epithelial layer loses cells and thins out and becomes atrophied, revealing choroidal vessels underneath. Hyper-reflective foci thus likely represent progression of AMD to later stages including geographic atrophy and choroidal neovascularization.

answers.answerText: D. Greater risk of cystoid macular edema
E. No significant differences have been found between patient with AMD that present with intraretinal hyper-reflective foci vs those that do not.
